RATS scurry away down the scum-covered steps as the GLOW LANTERN and FOOTSTEPS herald someone's arrival...

emerges around the bend. Mid-30s. Cultured beauty. Her dr face are smeared with grime and... is that blood we see t only knows what's happened to her. Genvieve ducks under a monstrous cobweb as she passes an window.

LIGHTNING streaks across the night sky outside. We catch of the MOON disappearing behind the clouds. Genvieve reaches the bottom of the stairs. The tomb itsel Water trickles in through cracks in the lichen-covered wa pooling on the tomb floor. Genvieve moves forward, her lantern throwing distorted sh over everything... In front of her is Anton LeMarche's stone sarcophagus. Genvieve kneels in the water, one hand resting on the spi railing which surrounds the tomb. She reaches the other h towards a scum-covered plaque, brushing the grime away... THUNDER and LIGHTNING reach a crescendo as... A SKELETAL HAND rises out of the water, reaching for her. Genvieve SCREAMS. The lantern falls from her grasp, sputt out. The hand reaches for her arm and inadvertently clutc breast instead... Genvieve starts to laugh hysterically.
(exasperated)
Cut! Thank you, Renee. Can we throw some light on the set?
I'm sorry... Suddenly it is lighter. Genvieve can't stop laughing. The monster hand disappears back beneath the water.
It's not 1865. The LeMarche Castle tomb is in fact, a 90s set. We are inside a soundstage, on a raised set, so the should really read...

A FILM CREW scurries about. Everyone is LAUGHING now. The sits to the right. He and the DP are already huddled over video-assist monitor. We see the previous scene rewinding speed. The FIRST A.D. moves in.
Water in the pool's running low, fill her up! Crewmembers move towards the set. An SFX PUPPETEER (i.e., the skeletal arm) crawls out from followed by an ELECTRICIAN.
I can't see shit down there! I'm working blind!
rises out of the water. Her name is actually RENEE HALLOW beauty is undeniable, even in such a disheveled state.

This is great, I could've spent four months on a romantic comedy with Warren Beatty, and instead, I've got a horny zombie trying to cop a feel! The crew members LAUGH. She's well-liked on the set. Rene Wardrobe and make-up personnel move in to adjust Renee's  appearance.
Uhgh, there's water everywhere... (beat)

Can I get a cigarette? The MAKE-UP GIRL pulls a pack of cigarettes from her fann and offers Renee one. In a flash, a P.A. appears with a l Renee mumbles "thanks" as she fires up. She squints her e trying to see past the set lights.
(calling out)
Geoff? (beat)
Anybody see my boy?
Right here, Mom... GEOFF MATTHEWS, Renee's 12 year-old son steps into view. face lights up when she sees him.
How long have you been here?
Couple minutes. I saw the last shot. That was pretty cool. Renee grimaces as the make-up girl spritzes her face with bottle.
(casually)
How did it go with your father last night?
Good. He said he'd be over for dinner at eight... (awkward)
I mean... he misses you, Mom...
I miss him too...
(continuing)
I just don't want you to get your hopes up, okay? We're trying to work things out, but... Her voice trails off.
I know, Mom.
(affectionate)

You know everything, don't you? Renee and Geoff are interrupted by a CREWMEMBER who's spr "atmosphere" about the set with a hand-held smoke machine coughs. Off-set, the FIRST A.D. is trying to get the show on the
Okay, people! Quiet! We're going to try this another time!
Guess it's showtime.
Yep. Renee kisses Geoff on the forehead. He takes the cigarett her and moves off the set, standing near the camera. The director turns back toward Renee.
Alright, Renee. Last time. I promise. We nail this and you won't have to do this ever again.
That's what you said the first time... Renee turns and heads back toward the stairs. A P.A. hand new lantern. As she reaches the stairs, the house lights creating the proper atmosphere once again.
The puppeteer gets ready. It's cramped. The electrician c power box connection. The director nods to the camera operator.
Rolling. Speed...
"Castle of Terror." Scene 69A. Take thirteen. The slate comes down.
Action! The scene replays itself as before, only now we're watchi action from multiple viewpoints. We start on the video assist monitor, then move up to...
He grins as he watches the scene unfold.
Renee has reached the sarcophagus. LIGHTNING flashes. The hand bursts up, grabbing Renee's arm. The scene continues original point of interruption.
We see an undetected LEAK. Water drips down. The puppetee position, struggling, and... ...knocks over the power box which SPARKS just as...
Renee/Genvieve grabs the iron railing with both hands. Electricity surges through Renee. Her body jerks and writ some nightmarish marionette.
The electrician drags the puppeteer back. Sparks fly.
Jesus! We've crossed over into 220! Shut down the generator!
Crewmembers SCREAM and scramble back... All the circuits are blowing, lights EXPLODING and shower sparks over the whole set. This is not part of the movie.

It's awful. She shakes, her SMOKING HANDS frozen to the i railing by the electricity running through her... Suddenly, Renee falls forward against the iron. Her face SMOKE AND SINGE... The lights CONTINUE TO BLOW, casting a strobic effect ove soundstage, adding to the chaos.
As he witnesses the whole event. He tries to rush forward someone restrains him...
Mom!!!! Suddenly all the circuits in the stage are blown and the OUT. Renee slumps back into the water, smoke trailing up still form. And we...
An aged GOLDEN RETRIEVER is on the surgical table. CHASE D.V.M., gently strokes the dog's fur. He's good with the kind. The retriever's owners: a MOTHER and her SON, look
I think this is probably for the best. He's a very old dog. He has arthritis. He has cataracts in his eyes... Chase looks at the mother. He's always hated this part.
He's had a good life... (to dog)
...haven't you, boy?
Doctor Matthews, your son is on line one. He says it's an emergency... Chase breaks concentration, pulling his eyes away from th and son.

A blur of activity converges on the movie set. A TRIO OF  PARAMEDICS. A FIRE OFFICIAL. A POLICE OFFICER. Medical eq Horrified crewmembers watch on, helpless. WE STAY ON Geoff, momentarily blocked out and then reveal and again, amidst the commotion of paramedics scrambling Renee. The director has his hand on Geoff's shoulder. Geoff's eyes dart about, taking it all in. Things are hap very fast: --Renee's hand is lifted. Someone checking her pulse. --H eyelids parted. A pen light flashing at her fixed pupils.

Run me down a line of normal saline. --An I.V. needle plunges into the inside of Renee's elbow syringe injects into the I.V. post. --Hands hook up a life-pack monitor. Renee's dress is tor Electrodes press to bare skin. --The monitor screen blink life.
We have a bradycardic rhythm at 30. --Another PARAMEDIC dials out on a cellular phone, to the consulting physician.
White female. Approximately thirty five years old. Electrocution... --A clear tube is inserted down her throat. --The monitor erratic heartbeat.
She's in V-fib. --There's a renewed urgency even amidst their rush. --Defibrillator paddles are pressed to her chest. Geoff looks to the monitor as... --It goes to flatline.
Clear.
No... Geoff moves forward, pulling away from the director. The officer moves in and intercepts Geoff, turning the boy aw Geoff's eyes fix on the monitor. An unbending flatline...
You have to bring her back... Chase rushes onto the set, pushing past crewmembers. He f the sight of the horrific commotion around Renee's still
Oh Jesus... Chase's gaze connects with his son.
(helpless)
Dad... We pull back from Geoff, Chase, and the commotion around Farther and farther as the darkness around the set begins in...
(urgent)
We're losing her... Darkness everywhere and we

A form drifts forward, materializing out of the fog. It's a CASKET. Appearing as if it's floating among the cl PULLING BACK, WE SEE that it's moving along A CONVEYOR. A WE CAN make out the faint form of A PLANE as the conveyor from the cargo compartment. The casket reaches the end of the conveyor. A tag marks i destination: Bangor, Maine. HANDS reach in and lift the c FOUR BAGGAGE HANDLERS hoist the casket up onto their shou carry it off.
Is it true she grew up around here?
Yeah. Over in Ludlow.
Huh. Never met a movie star before.
Well you're a little late for an autograph. The baggage handlers laugh as they walk off into the dist fog closes around them and we...
We drift down from the gray sky to the somber scene below the distance, a crowd of MOURNERS are gathered around a g
...I am the resurrection and the life, saith the Lord...
THE HEADSTONE is adorned with an iron plaque. It reads, s RENEE HALLOW MATTHEWS 1955-1991

...She that believeth in me, though she were dead, yet shall she live; and whosoever liveth and believeth in me, shall never die... THE CASKET is slowly lowered into the open grave. As it d WE SEE Geoff and his father, Chase, standing at the foref the crowd. Renee's grave is next to those of her parents. Among the mourners is MARJORIE HARGROVE, an attractive lo in her early twenties. Further down the hillside, a wall of NEWS REPORTERS are g behind a roped-off media boundary. There is a blinding fl PHOTO FLASHES as the press records the scene before them. A SHERIFF'S DEPARTMENT PATROL CAR cruises up the cemetery pulling to a stop near the mob of reporters. Out of the car steps GUS GILBERT. Gus is nearly forty, wi Sheriff's uniform fitted to his solid, ageless frame. Gru a little self-important: Gus likes being a big fish in a pond.
(drawing near)

Let's keep it back, folks. Try to show her a little respect... A REPORTER ducks under the media boundary, moving in for shot. He doesn't make it two steps before he's intercepted by G grabs the reporter and shoves him back.
Hey! What did I just say? Gus means business. One look into his eyes reveals his in nonsense approach.
Ass-hole... The reporter backs off.

Beneath the gloomy, ominous skies, the lines on Chase's f him as a decade older than his thirty-five years. Chase g places a comforting hand on Geoff's shoulder. Geoff inches forward, pulling free of Chase's touch. Draw mother, drawn from his father. The only blemishes on his rosy cheeks are the tears, the endless tears.
I know that my redeemer liveth, and that he shall stand at the latter day upon the earth. Geoff looks upon the casket, gazing into the abyss of des

The crowd has dispersed. Geoff is standing at the base of Renee's grave. His eyes Unmoving. Unaccepting. Chase is nearby, watching, not wanting to intrude on Geof private moment. Gus quietly moves in at Chase's side.
Did she always have reporters following her around like this?
Pretty much so. Gus glances at Geoff.
I hear you moved into town.
I wanted to get Geoff out of L.A. Just start things over, you know? Gus nods. Now his eyes fall on Renee's headstone.
I remember when Renee left. She couldn't wait to get out of Ludlow. She used to say that life moved too slow here... Chase forces a smile.
That's Renee alright.
I suppose so. The sky above seems heavy with imminent rain and we...

Lazy oaks embrace a vintage, two-story Victorian home in neighborhood of Ludlow, Maine. A commercial MOVING VAN is out front. Marjorie, the girl we saw at Renee's funeral, is coming d sidewalk. She checks the address on the front of the hous heads up the driveway.

Moving boxes clutter the downstairs. Chase is weaving through the maze, doing an inventory on boxes. A sweaty PAIR OF MOVERS are climbing up the stairs. Each hunched  over, with a garment box balanced on his back. T of each carton is boldly labeled: RENEE - ATTIC.
We've got six more of these. You sure you want them all in the attic? Chase is contemplating a compromise when Geoff appears fr kitchen doorway.
...Geoff, what if we just give the clothes to Goodwill? We'll keep the rest. Just the clothes. Geoff shakes his head, firm and deliberate denial.
You're the one who wanted to move. Nobody would've touched them if you didn't want to move here... Chase weakens, giving in.
All the 'Renee' boxes go in the attic. Sorry. Marjorie KNOCKS on the open frame of the front door. Geoff recognizes her from his mother's funeral. She flash warm smile.

Hi. I'm Marjorie Hargrove. Your new housekeeper. Marjorie has a naive, friendly quality about her. She's a blessed with eye-popping genetics. Standing there outside door, looking more than a little nervous... we can't help her. Needless to say, she doesn't look like your typical  housekeeper.
(re: Chase's reaction)
Is something wrong?
Uh... no. You just... look different than you sounded on the phone. Please, come in. Marjorie enters. She grins at Geoff again. Yep. She's ner alright.
I'm real excited about working for you Mr. Matthews...
Well we're glad to have you, Marjorie. You can call me Chase, by the way. Marjorie passes her curious eyes over one of Renee's garm containers.
I've always admired Ms. Hallow. That scene she did in Blue Midnight, where her lover meets her at the train station... (she sighs)

I must've watched that movie four times. Chase smiles. Marjorie's enthusiasm is endearing. Just then, one of the movers loses his grip. A garment bo down the slope of the stairs. When it reaches the bottom, spill over the floor.
Oh. I'll get that... Marjorie moves for the spill. The first dress she touches beaded peach evening gown. Her fingers linger on the fabr
This is gorgeous. She wore this at the Emmys, didn't she? Geoff moves forward, acting overly defensive.
Hey, don't touch her stuff. It made her crazy when people touched her stuff. Marjorie is taken aback by the oddity of Geoff's statemen Chase catches her eye, shrugging apologetically.
A VAN is parked outside. The rear side panel is masked of tape and a stencil. Chase grabs the corner of the tape an carefully peels it back, revealing a crisp, new business
Serving Aroostook County
ESTABLISHING. Shops and businesses situated around a lazy square. QUiet. Relaxed. As rural as they come. WE pick up Chase's van as it cruises by.

Chase pulls the van in front of an unassuming veterinary On the door is Chase's nameplate. And on the weathered wa outline of letters where the name and title "Quentin Yola Doctor of Veterinary Medicine" once was. Geoff is first out of the van.

Geoff and Chase move inside. The offices look like they w in the 40s. A dark corridor stretches down the center of suite. Faded green walls are solid, with few exteriors. I creepy in here. Heavy, grey plastic curtains absorb much of the light whi find its way in. Nothing looks like it's been updated in fifty years.
This doesn't look so bad... Chase sweeps a curtain aside, revealing the interior to G Dust swirls in the air.
How long ago did this guy retire?
It's been a few years. Geoff takes a look around, growing uncomfortable.
(skeptical)
A few? Geoff moves on down the central corridor which seems to g darker and more dismal with every step. He moves on into boarding room...

Rows of kennels are stacked along the walls, smothered wi cobwebs. Ancient, rusted surgical equipment is scattered  everywhere. The place is a mess. Windows are boarded up a shadows cloak the room. Over to the right, Geoff hears a RUSTLING. A CARDBOARD BOX on one of the shelves jiggles. Something around inside it. Geoff's eyes widen. Still, morbid curiosity propels him f The box rustles again. He reaches for it and... A CREATURE LEAPS out at him, HOWLING. Geoff SCREAMS and j back. The box tumbles over and... A CAT crawls out. Behind the protective mother, are four cutest kittens we've ever seen, MEWING away. Geoff sighs just as Chase rushes into the room.
What's wrong?!
(embarrassed)
Nothing. I just got spooked by a bunch of furballs. Inside the box is a note. Chase reaches for it. It reads: warm welcome to you."
Great, now I've opened an orphanage too. One of the kittens pads out of the box and looks up at Ge sleepy eyes. Her fur is striped.
Well, I'll take one. If it's okay... Geoff lifts the fragile creature, cradling it in his arms
She looks like a tiger. Chase spies an old broom resting in the corner.

Tell you what, you do some sweeping up here, and she's yours. Geoff nods and Chase moves back out into the hallway. Geoff sets the box back upright and lowers Tiger in with kittens. He reaches for the broom and goes to work sweepi the cobwebs. Just as soon as he turns his back, Tiger climbs the side box, spilling over onto the floor.
Chase is unpacking a shipment of medical supplies. When h them in the cabinet, he stirs up a layer of dust. Tiger scampers by as Chase coughs his way out of the clou dust.

Tiger sees the front door ajar. And as she approaches to what lies beyond-- The door swings open... ZOWIE, A SIBERIAN HUSKY is staring back at her. He's blac white with blue eyes, with a mask that is at once menacin majestic. A pudgy thirteen year old boy, DREW, has a hold of the do collar. Zowie's BARK sends Tiger scrambling. Drew loses his grip as Zowie yanks free. A strong, patern command calls after Drew from outside.
Drew, you get a handle on that dog, now!

Chase spins around at the commotion as Tiger darts across floor with the barking dog in pursuit. Mayhem ensues as Zowie's big paws slip on the slick tile. Geoff rushes in from the boarding area. Tiger ducks beneath the back of a surgical gurney. Zowie's snoot wedges beneath the base, inches from Tiger' striking paw. Drew slides in on his knees, renewing his hold on Zowie's He pulls the dog back. Geoff rescues Tiger from beneath the gurney. Drew shrugs sheepishly.
Sorry. He gets kinda hyper... Drew's stepfather, Gus Gilbert, enters. The dreaded, domi voice of authority in Drew's life. WE know him as the she Renee's funeral.
Hell, he thought it was lunch. How ya doin', Chase? (a handshake)
You haven't met my boy. (aside)
Drew, where the hell are your manners. Drew steps forward and awkwardly offers his hand to Chase Geoff. The boys shake.
He's a cool lookin' dog. Zowie lurches forward, eager to shower affection on Geoff strokes the dog's soft mane.
What's his name?
Zowie. Drew puts his palm under Zowie's chin and turns him for C see. There are several scabbed-over gashes on his left ch
Damn dog stuck his nose in on my rabbits and they ganged up on him. I swear that dog's an idiot.
Is he gonna be okay? With one eye on Zowie, Chase sprays some antiseptic on th examination table and wipes it clean.

Let's have him hop up here. Drew prods Zowie. Zowie jumps up onto the table. Chase lo the facial lacerations, then turns on a penlight and exam dog's eyes. Gus passes a lingering look over Tiger. He reaches in to making sure it meets with Geoff's approval.
When I was young I thought cats were the girls and dogs were the boys.
There are three more girls where that one came from looking for homes. Drew perks up at the thought, but Gus shoots it down.
Not our home. Chase takes the light out of Zowie's eyes. He looks to Gu
Thee facial lacerations should heal up pretty quickly. I'll give you som antibiotic cream--
--Drew, he's your dog. Are you listening to this? Chase turns to Drew and continues...
His left eye is scratched, corneal abrasion. Eyedrops will help, but it's going to take som time. Try to keep him away from those rabbits, huh? Drew nods, casting a glance aside at Gus.
(to Chase)
I hear you've got Marjorie Hargrove working for you now.
How'd you know that? Gus gives Chase a knowing grin.
It's a small town, Chase. Gus laughs and claps Chase on the shoulder.
Hey Geoff, did you know your mother and I used to be high- school sweethearts? Geoff is surprised at this. Surprised and annoyed. Tact i quality that Gus possesses in abundance.
Really?
(nodding)
Homecoming. Prom. Whole nine yards. (to Chase)
Course that was a lifetime ago.
JUNIOR HIGH SCHOOL KIDS are converging en masse for class Chase's van pulls up front.
Chase digs some cash out of his wallet. Geoff stares out school. He's dreading this.
What's a lunch cost these days? You want ten?
(unenthused)
Sure. Chase looks at his son.
You nervous? New town, new school. I know it must be pretty hard for you...
(cutting him off)
I'll be fine, Dad. Geoff reaches for the door, but Chase stops him. He's try reach his son. He really is.
(awkward)
Geoff... you have to help me out here a little... "MEOW!" Chase drops his eyes to the bulge squirming aroun Geoff's jacket. He can't help but smile.
Are you sure you don't want me to pick you up. It's a long ride. Geoff opens the side panel of the van and slips out his M BIKE.
That's what my bike's for... Before Chase can say another word, Geoff is gone.
As Chase pulls away, WE SEE the handmade sign taped in th window:

Drew is among a small circle of BOYS. He recognizes Geoff his bike from the van. The largest of the boys, CLYDE, ta notice of the unfamiliar face. Clyde is fifteen, going on twenty. You know the type: loc held back a year or two.

Check it out. That's the new kid. The son of that movie star. Mischief gleams in Clyde's eyes as he watches Geoff's eve The other boys follow suit. Clyde always takes the lead. Geoff fields their penetrating stares. For a second his e connect with Clyde's, then he moves on into the building. Among the boys, Drew is the reluctant participant.
MRS. GORDON is addressing a room of SEVENTH GRADERS. Geoff is doodling in his notebook, feeling acutely out of he tries to avoid the curious glances the rest of his new classmates are giving him.

People, this is Geoff Matthews. He'll be joining our class for the rest of the school year... As Mrs. Gordon points to him, Geoff drops his face even l This is the worst embarrassment a boy could ever suffer. to throttle Mrs. Gordon. A freckle-faced boy, DOUG, fires off a question.
Hey, what's Hollywood like? Do you know Eddie Murphy?
(annoyed)
No.
Why don't we save that for later, Doug? A girl with braces, SUSAN, continues the interrogation.
What about Julia Roberts?

Susan! That'll be enough. Susan shuts up. Geoff sinks even lower in his seat. The kids turn their eyes back to the front of the room. But one classmate's eyes are still on Geoff. It's Clyde. Clyde shifts his stare to the squirming lump in Geoff's j catches a glimpse of Tiger's bobbing nose popping out.

Geoff joins the stampede of kids as the BELL releases the day. Almost immediately, Clyde and his cronies, STEVIE AN fall in step behind him. Drew hangs slightly off to the s really wanting to be a part of the intimidation.

What's the hurry, Junior? Where you off to? Clyde quickens his pace, pulling ahead of Geoff and stopp front of him. Stevie and Brad move in on either side. Sur by peers, it's apparent how small Geoff is for his age. On the wall next to them is a bulletin board display. Cly glances at it. Geoff follows his gaze.
It's one of those corny school affairs with construction letters spelling out: "WE REMEMBER RENEE HALLOW." Beneath pictures of Renee clipped from various magazines. Cloying tasteless.
(feigning remorse)
Too bad about your Mom. Papers said it was pretty gross, getting fried like that. Guess you saw it, huh? Geoff nods. Clyde raises his eyebrows, pulling Geoff's ja open.
So, what are you hiding there?
When you bring a friend to school you're supposed to introduce him. Geoff's arm tightens protectively around Tiger.
Her name's Tiger.
Tiger? Don't you think that's kind of a pussy name? (reaching out)

Can I hold her? I promise I'll be real careful. Clyde has a convincing way about him. Geoff reluctantly h kitten over. Clyde is so gentle with the creature that on never question his sincerity. Geoff is just beginning to feel at ease when something ch Clyde's tone, something sinister.
Hey, Geoff. You ever seen a kitten run?
I've seen her run around the house. Clyde's eyes narrow. He takes a couple of steps back. Geo heart starts to sink.
No, I mean really run... (beat)
Like this! Clyde backsteps and bolts off down the hallway with Tiger and Stevie fall in behind him, laughing. Drew shrugs apologetically. He's torn, but he tears off a nonetheless.
Shit... Geoff runs off in pursuit of them.

Geoff rushes from the building, searching the dispersing There they are, tearing from the bike racks, pedaling for street. Clyde sees Geoff and mockingly holds the kitten out for d they ride by. Geoff runs for the bike racks.

Clyde and his cohorts break from the outskirts of town, r onto the open road. Clyde glances back toward the center of town. Geoff is so far behind he's barely visible. Clyde returns his eyes to the road ahead, raising Tiger n nose with him.
Having fun yet? Clyde and his smirking buddies ride on, OUT OF FRAME.
giving the pedals all he can, struggling to keep pace wit boys.

Scattered houses sprinkle the landscape ahead. Cochran La stretches into the distance beyond the housing. Clyde's clan cuts from the road and blazes a trail across residential property. The two-story house is weathered an up. It looks vaguely familiar. Creepy. And when WE FIND the mailbox post, we know why. The name but there's no question who once lived there. Five bold l
Geoff whips by in a blur, still in pursuit.
Clyde and his friends have abandoned their bikes. They've position on top of the slope of the hill, standing at the THE PATH TO THE PET SEMATARY.
Geoff pulls his bike to a stop short of the boys. He dism leans it up against a tree.
Just give me the cat, all right? A devilish grin creeps over Clyde. He strolls down the pa Geoff. Clyde grabs Geoff's handlebars and, backing up, pu and the bike with him.
I would but... there was a little accident... (feeding off Geoff's alarm)

She was trying to get away. You know, running down my leg... and her head got too close to the  spokes. Pretty gross. What's left of her is up in the Pet Sematary. A zip-lock bag might help... (shrugs)
...but I happen to be out of them at the moment. Drew shakes his head, disgusted he has to put up with Cly antics.
Come on, Clyde, just tell him where the cat is...
(turning on Drew)

...I TOLD HIM where the cat is! Now shut up, fuck-face! Clyde punches Drew in the arm. Drew shrinks back. Geoff flashes a hateful stare at Clyde. All of the boys but Clyde are uncomfortably silent. There something frightening about Clyde... something that exten the standard bully antics. We begin to get the feeling th kid is genuinely deranged.
(relishing the moment)
You heard about the Creed murders yet? And the place where the dead come back to life? He motions to the path behind him.
(continuing)
It's just back there. Just down that path...
(meekly)
Clyde... it's not funny anymore.
Oh? So you got a problem? What're you gonna do, fat-ass? You gonna sic big, bad, old Gus after me? Drew shuts up. Clyde turns back to Geoff, drawing closer.

What do you think, Geoff? Maybe you could dig up your Mom and take her back there. Maybe if you pray real hard, she'll come back. With this last remark Clyde has pushed too far. Geoff's f red with anger.
(quietly)
Just give me the cat, ass-hole. Clyde's grin falters a moment.
Excuse me, maybe I'm a little hard of hearing... but did you just call me an ass-hole? Clyde pokes Geoff in the shoulder.
You mad, Geoff? Cause if you are, you should take a shot at me... This time Clyde shoves Geoff back even harder.

Come on, you pussy! What's the matter with you? Clyde moves forward again and Geoff suddenly LASHES OUT, everyone off guard. For an instant, Drew marvels at Geoff's tenacity. Clyde LUNGES. He hammers Geoff with blows. Outsizing him by forty pounds, Clyde tosses Geoff to the Geoff struggles, but Clyde's grip proves arresting. Clyde throws Geoff onto his stomach, forcing his face int dirt. It looks as if he's ready to smother his opponent. Drew is the first to rush in. Brad and Stevie quickly fol takes all three of them to peel Clyde off Geoff. Clyde gets to his feet and backs away. There's great plea his crazed eyes as he watches Geoff coughing and gasping.
Fuckin' ass-hole. Satisfied he's handed out enough ill will for the day, Cl away. Drew's attentions remain on Geoff. As Clyde strolls by, h Drew's arm and swings him around.

This way, fat-boy. Stevie and Brad follow. As the group passes Geoff's bike, gives it a kick, knocking it over. Then they're gone. Geoff pulls himself to his feet. Brushing off the mess, h up the path in search of Tiger.

The woods here have grown long with shadows. The air is s the sound of birds is conspicuously absent. A WOODEN ARCHWAY frames the entrance to the primitive gra Scrawled across the weatherstained boards is a child's ba legible attempt at "PET SEMATARY." Geoff trepidatiously enters the clearing of crude, crowde Collars, leashes, bird cages and other accessories adorn makeshift crosses and headstones. Geoff moves along the outer circle of markers, each craft child's caring hands. As he searches, he can't help but notice the heartfelt ep On the outer circle, he sees a crate-board marker memoria SMUCKY THE CAT... HE WAS OBEDIANT. MOVING INWARD, the markers are older. The ones he can sti convey a sense of the perpetual cycle of life and death. Here is a wide, flat, upright board planted deep in the e Memory of MARTA our Pet Rabit Dyed March 1 1965." The next three rows are illegible, the inscriptions are w beyond recognition... And then, chiseled into sandstone: THE BEST DOG THAT EVER LIVED 1929-1939. And now... "MEOW." Faint. But very much alive. Geoff picks up his pace, weaving quickly toward the cente There, he finds Tiger. Trapped in a rusted old birdcage, swallowed by the grave. Geoff opens the door and frees Tiger, stroking the trembl kitten. Geoff's eyes are drawn to the far perimeter... to the dea THE DEADFALL looms on the outskirts of the clearing like skeletal remains. An abstract stairway to things beyond. picks up just then, sending leaves skittering in waves ac ground.
When Geoff turns around, he finds Drew waiting for him un archway. Drew smiles, full of respect for Geoff.
I've never seen anybody punch Clyde before.
(shrugs)
He pissed me off.
